BusinessName.BusinessNameLine1Txt: TRUSTEES OF THE HAMLINE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Hamline University is a nationally ranked comprehensive university serving 4,500 students in its College of Liberal Arts, School of Education, and School of Business. It offers undergraduate, masters, doctorate and professional degrees, as well as certificate and continuing studies programs.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The mission of the university is to create a diverse and collaborative community of learning dedicated to the development of students' knowledge, values and skills for successful lives of leadership, scholarship and service.
IRS990.Desc: Hamline University is a nationally-ranked, comprehensive university serving nearly 4,500 students in its College of Liberal Arts, School of Education, and School of Business. It offers undergraduate, masters, doctoral and professional degrees, as well as certificate and continuing studies programs. Founded in 1854, Hamline University was the first institution of higher learning in Minnesota. The University has established a national reputation for academic quality, as well as providing students with personal attention and exceptional experiences. Hamline is one of just 283 Phi Beta Kappa institutions in the United States. Among comprehensive universities, U.S. News and World Report ranks Hamline in the top two in Minnesota in its category of Best Regional Universities. Hamline is ranked twenty-second in the nation by Washington Monthly's College Rankings of service-oriented schools. Hamline's School of Law operated through December 2015 when it combined with William Mitchell College of Law to establish the independent Mitchell Hamline School of Law. The financial results of the University include the impact of the law school combination, which directly contributed to the increase in the current year's net loss, in particular, by way of a significant one time write off of law library collections. Net assets were also impacted by the transfer of school specific restricted program funds and law school endowment assets to the newly combined school.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Hamline University provides academic support to its students through support services that are an integral part of the University's primary mission of instruction. This includes expenses for libraries, galleries, audio/visual services, academic development, academic computing support, course and curriculum development, and academic administration.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Hamline University provides student services to its students and includes such expenses as admissions, financial aid administration, registrar activities, and activities that contribute to students' emotional and physical well-being and to their intellectual, cultural, and social development outside the context of the formal instructional program.

ProgSrvcAccomActyOtherGrp.Desc: Hamline University provides auxiliary services to students which are essentially the self-supporting operations of the University. These services charge a fee to students that is directly related to, although not necessarily equal to, the cost of providing the service. Examples are residence halls, food services, student health services, and the campus bookstore.

Hamline University provides other program services by way of other offices and activities to support the program activities of the University. Expenses in this area include research expenses related to activities specifically organized to produce research outcomes, either commissioned by an agency external to the institution or separately budgeted by an organizational unit within the University. Expenses also include public service expenses related specifically to public service and for activities established primarily to provide non-instructional services beneficial to groups external to the institution. This includes expenses for the Wesley Center and the Mediation Center.

Form990PartVIISectionAGrp.TitleTxt: Sr VP of Business Finance and Technology
Interim Dean of School of Law and Professor

ProgramServiceRevenueGrp.Desc: Sales and Servised of Educational Activities

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The University engaged one firm to assist in legislative activities that affect the University and paid the firm $10,012. Also, the University is a member of Minnesota Private College Council (MPCC), an organization described in section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code. MPCC is an association of private nonprofit institutions of higher education that serves a variety of its members' shared needs, including, but not only, nonpartisan and non-electoral advocacy for public policy that meets students' needs and advances the interests of private higher education. The University paid membership dues to MPCC in the amount of $159,658 during the taxable year. MPCC has divided its expenses for its taxable year ending June 30, 2016, into two groups. Group 1 consists of those expenses that did not in any way support attempts to influence legislation within the meaning of section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code ("lobbying"), and Group 2 consists of all other expenses. Group 2 includes many expenses, such as personnel costs, that supported both lobbying and nonlobbying activities. MPCC did not attempt to allocate the Group 2 expenses between lobbying and nonlobbying activities. MPCC has determined that the amount of the Group 2 expenses represents 72.90% of the amount of the dues that MPCC collected in the same taxable year. Assuming that all Group 2 expenses were paid from member dues, and allocating those expenses pro rata based on the dues paid by each member, $116,391 of the University's dues were used to pay Group 2 expenses. The amount of lobbying expenses paid from the University's dues was significantly less than that amount.

The University's collections, which were acquired through purchases and contributions since the University's inception, are not recognized as assets on the balance sheet. Purchases of collection items are recorded as decreases in unrestricted net assets in the year in which the items are acquired or as temporarily restricted net assets if the assets that are used to purchase the items are restricted by the donors. Contributed collection items are not reflected on the financial statements. Proceeds from de-accessions or insurance recoveries are reflected as increases in th eappropriate net asset classes.

The University's collection is made up of pottery, prints, musical instruments and paintings that are held for educational and performance purposes. Each of the items is catalogued, preserved and card for and activities verifying their existence and assessing their condition are performed continuously.

The intended uses of the endowment funds are to establish a scholarship or prize, to create a chair in a specific academic area, to fund a particular research program, to fund other programs such as professorships, fellowships, library, buildings, equipment and lectures and discretionary use by the University (unrestricted).

The University publicizes its racially nondiscriminatory position in all major publications, including thse related to admission and student services and Hamline Magazine as well as on the University website.
The University receives federal and state funding.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The University does not monitor academic achievement of recipients for the purpose of qualification for assistance.

GrantsOtherAsstToIndivInUSGrp.GrantTypeTxt: Educational scholarships and financial assistance for students
Graduate tuition and fee reduction s and exemptions

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The financial aid office determines student eligibility for federal, state and institutional scholarships according to the University's established criteria which follows federal and state guidelines for awarding any grant funds. There is an annual audit to ensure compliance with these regulations.

RltdOrgOfficerTrstKeyEmplGrp.TitleTxt: Sr VP of Business Finance and Technology

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The former and current president have been provided these items by the University. The interim provost is provided a residence at a reduced cost.
The President of the University participates in a supplemental nonqualified retirement plan.
A written contract between the University and its President provides for a non-fixed payment. This payment is reflected in Schedule J, Part II, Column B(ii).

TaxExemptBondsIssuesGrp.PurposeDesc: REFUND OF PRIOR BOND AND REFINANCE A LOAN
BRIDGE LOAN FOR CONSTRUCTION OF UNIVERSITY CENTER

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: In 2015, the University entered into an agreement to combine the Hamline School of Law (HUSL) and William Mitchell College of Law (WMCL) conditional upon acquiescence from the accrediting body, the American Bar Association (ABA). The ABA granted acquiescence to combine HUSL with WMCL, and to recognize Mitchell Hamline School of Law (MHSL) as a fully ABA-approved law school effective on December 28, 2015. The newly combined school is located primarily on William Mitchell's existing campus. The MHSL is an autonomous, non-profit institution governed by an independent board of trustees.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 7a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Trustees of the University are elected by the Board of Trustees and ratified by the Minnesota Annual Conference of the United Methodist Church. The President of the University and the Bishop of the Conference are Ex Officio Trustees with full voting powers.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Form 990 was reviewed by management and the audit committee prior to being filed with the IRS. The Form 990 was provided to the Board of Trustees.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Audit committee of the Board of Trustees is responsible for monitoring and responding to conflicts of interest. An individual with a conflict of interest is required to abstain from discussions and voting on the issue.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The determination of compensation for the individuals identified included review and approval by independent persons, review of comparability data and contemporaneous substantiation of the decision.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The University's governing documents are available at the Minnesota Secretary of State's office. The University's financial statements are available on its website. The University's Form 990 is available at Guidestar.org or upon request. The University's conflict of interest policy is available to the public on its website.

During the year, the fair value of 60 endowment funds were legally transferred from the University to another educational institution (Mitchell Hamline School of Law) due to the discontinued operations of the University's School of Law ($3,605,696). In addition, seventy-six temporarily restricted funds were transferred. These funds represented prior year's excess appropriations from the endowment funds or law-school specific funds ($604,407). Also, pledges attributed to the School of Law were written off when operations ceased. The pledges were originally designated to temporarily and permanently restricted funds ($84,000 and $105,000), respectively.
